title: Waynesville-St. Robert Regional Airport
text:
Waynesville-St. Robert Regional Airport , also known as Forney Field, is a public and military use airport located at <a href="Fort%20Leonard%20Wood">Fort Leonard Wood</a> in <a href="Pulaski%20County%2C%20Missouri">Pulaski County</a>, <a href="Missouri">Missouri</a>, United States. The airport's passenger terminal is operated under the control of the <a href="U.S.%20Army">U.S. Army</a> and general aviation is under the direction of a board named by the cities of <a href="Waynesville%2C%20Missouri">Waynesville</a> and <a href="St.%20Robert%2C%20Missouri">St. Robert</a>. Formerly known as Waynesville Regional Airport at Forney Field, it is served by one commercial airline with scheduled service subsidized by the <a href="Essential%20Air%20Service">Essential Air Service</a> program.
It is included in the <a href="National%20Plan%20of%20Integrated%20Airport%20Systems">National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems</a> for 2021–2025, which <a href="FAA%20airport%20categories">categorized</a> it as a "non-primary commercial service" airport (between 2,500 and 10,000 enplanements per year).
History.
During World War II the airfield was used by the <a href="United%20States%20Army%20Air%20Forces">United States Army Air Forces</a>. It was known as Forney Army Airfield until 1998. It was attached to <a href="Fort%20Leonard%20Wood">Fort Leonard Wood</a> and was part of the <a href="Army%20Service%20Forces">Army Service Forces</a>.
Facilities and aircraft.
Waynesville-St. Robert Regional Airport covers an area of 237 <a href="acre">acre</a>s (96 <a href="hectare">ha</a>) at an <a href="elevation">elevation</a> of 1,159 feet (353 m) above <a href="mean%20sea%20level">mean sea level</a>. It has one <a href="runway">runway</a> designated 15/33 with an asphalt surface measuring 6,037 by 150 feet (1,840 x 46 m). For the 12-month period ending December 31, 2016, the airport had 25,807 aircraft operations, an average of 71 per day: 50% <a href="military%20aviation">military</a>, 32% <a href="general%20aviation">general aviation</a> and 18% <a href="airline">scheduled commercial</a>. In June 2021, there were 14 aircraft based at this airport: 9 single-engine and 5 military.
